THIS GAME IS TOO FUN FOR ITS OWN GOOD

It looks like a troll game, and in some ways it kind of is (you get to marry a teacher, kiss a bunny doll, call yourself Mary Sue, give your soul to a demon and whatnot), but its charming characters, good humor, and well-written plots made me genuinely like this game. I love playing this game. The biggest downside is its somewhat mediocre art style/character design, but I managed to get used to that, and even the art has its own weird sense of charm as well. I'd recommend Magical Diary to anyone who likes visual novels and interactive stories -- the dating aspect isn't even a requirement in this game, you can just have a really kick-ass school year if you wanted to! The amount of options in this game is really quite impressive and refreshing.

(On a final note, in my opinion, Grabiner is totally the best path)

13805558.review:
With the addition of the Magic System, this studio has managed something truly astounding:

This game is at the same time insultingly simple, and yet an absolute mess of trial and error gameplay.




In General, Dating Sims of any kind get measured by an different standard compared to most games. At its best the Genre is Character Development/Discovery condensed. Saddly most studios use that excuse to release sub-par titles with little to no imagination and even less effort, and while Magical Diary may not lack the latter, it definetly lacks imagination.


The Characters: Copy Paste. You've seen it before, you'll see it again. A forgettable parade of cliches.

The Choices: Linear in all but appearance. Choose in whoose pants you want to get and stick with it. This would be less of a problem if not for....

Gameplay and Story integration:  The Holy Grail of all dating sims.    Does it feel like you are playing the game, or like you are gaming the system?  Magical Diary takes the sledgehammer approach to subtlety and even those unafiliated with the Genre will see any character twist coming for miles.
Except for the magic system, which I had alluded to earlier. Along with the usual fair of stats, as the game progresses you  get to learn a selection of different colour coded magics. In theory you get to use these to influence the events arround you. In practice, the rather ethereal description, limited application of every spell, and utter lack of audio-visual cues, I often felt thrown back into the era of Adventure games, where every puzzle was solved by liberaly rubbing anything in your inventory on anything in the environment.
That's where the game steps in, and limits just what you can try via an MP-Gauge, or simply time constraint.


I'm sure after a second or third playthrough I could have gotten the results I wanted, but the entirely predictable characters, and obvious right/wrong choice system left me with little desire to play again.


All in all Magical Diary is rather tragic: A novel idea that lacks any kind of substance to back it up.

I was very pleasantly surprised by this.  Don't be put off by the generated anime character designs, Magical Diary creates an interesting world chock-full of three dimensional characters.  The story exists along with you, and can become very serious if you let it.

Functionally, Magical Diary is first and foremost a Visual Novel, but during the course of the game, you unlock a bunch of spells that you can use freely within a first-person old school dungeon crawl styled puzzle section. Some of the spells feel a little useless, and you don't get enough mana to really explore your options, but the later ones are pretty interesting once you've got a good spellbook down.  Learning spells directly comes from attending classes, which gives you level up points towards a style of magic.

This is one of the best Role Playing Games (in the true sense of the phrase, playing a role) I've played in quite a while.  Definitely recommended.

13301519.review:
This game was great fun, and totally worth the money, though it could have been much better. In general I don't like the anime look or wacky sense of humor but the progressiveness and impossible strangeness made this a very interesting experience.
The world is clearly based off of Harry Potter, with a sham Severus Snape and students group into houses (On a side note, I named my character Serpentina Hissmark and I laughed when she was glad not to be in the Snake house. But on one playthrough she was transferred- yay!). However, it's not a rip-off and has it's own unique feel. 
 I would say the strict gameplay element is limited- there aren't enough chances to use magic, especially outside of exams. The exams, composed of using spells learned in class to escape dungeons, are great fun. There are five fields of magic based on colors, and the game would have been far more interesting if the outcomes were more based on which fields the player specialized in. 
Instead, the real interest in the came comes from the visual novel element, a feature that I usually enjoy less. It seems that this game focused less on the fantasy fulfilment of the perfect lover, or one of a 'type' of perfect lover, and actually made realistic characters with interesting storylines.  However while a few of the paths were fairly standard (oddly enough, these included the lesbian paths! I think a few of the non-human ladies would have made better romantic interests) two of the male characters offered very unique and at times surprisingly touching romance options. I was genuinely rooting for one of my couples during a play-through, though the relationship was far from traditional. All I need to say is that a possible sham marriage with your Severus Snape stand-in professor is NOT the most WTF relationship option. I appreciated the fluid sexualities of the characters, the character of Professor Potsdam and her very enlightened views on teen sexuality and transgenderism, and the presentation of a friend's realistic abusive relationship. The game allows you to enter an worse-than-Edward-Cullen manner abusive relationship yourself, but it's up to you to interpret whether it's a good or bad thing. 
I do find it slighty annoying how you were pushed so quickly into a relationship with the demon, and the others were more difficult. I had to look online to find most of the paths, and I think there should be more hints and opportunities to pursue characters. In some cases, you need to be taking a certain class on a certain day, which I find too random.

13061070.review:
I liked parts of this game and disliked other parts.

Pros:
- Different & unique romance options! I loved that I could go for one of my female roommates. :)
- You get to customize your characters hair, eyes, and body type. This makes the protagonist feel more "yours."
- The characters get put in absolutely hilarious situations. 
- Your choices in the plot certainly have a big impact and can lead you to many different routes, so replay value is deifnitely there.
- The "magical school" setting is unique compared to some other dating sims.

Cons:
- I felt like the personality traits were worthless. I saw no point in getting points in the "cute/weird/smart" categories because they don't seem to affect anything.
- The magical tests never seem to get interesting/complex.
- Art was subpar. The characters all look similar in the face and their appearance doesn't change a whole lot. It starts to feel monotonous. 
- There are huuuuge chunks of dialogue/description with no pictures sometimes, which gets annoying. With such a cool, magical setting, I would expect to actually see some of the magic going on. Unfortunately, you never do. This is what makes this dating sim way less enjoyable than ones like Dandelion, which go above and beyond with scenery and drawing out pivotal scenes. The only time Magical Diary shows you a picture to go with a scene is if you kiss somebody, which for me, was only twice.

Overall: If you tend to like visual novels or dating sims, this one is worth a try, especially if you value the choice to either date men or women. However, don't expect this game to knock your socks off. It's entertaining, but somewhat underwhelming at times.

12274968.review:
Getting through school isn't always easy. The puzzles (exams) aren't always easy but they have several ways to complete. In the end, your choices in dialogue matter more than your time spent in class. Depending on how fast you read and how long you ponder your choices, the game length varies greatly.

You always play as a young woman with customizeable name and looks. The game has multiple romance choices, both male, female, teacher/student and otherworldly. All of them offer [i]interesting[/i] paths. There's no sexual content.

It's also worth a second playthrough (if you enjoy these kind of games) as it has lots of hidden paths (mostly based on romance options). You can fast-forward the scenes you've already read during your second playthrough.

Earns bonus points for totally random events, like getting spanked or offer your soul to a demon...

12272991.review:
I started it off not really knowing what to expect, and thought that it didn't give you enough choices. After classes start up though, the game gets really fun. Learning new spells and finding applications for them is fun. Mostly you will use them to get out of dungeons, which function as exams, but you will also be able to use many of them to unlock unique options in random events, which is an awesome touch. Speaking of random events, there are enough things that happen each week to make the game interesting, and a surprising amount of variety in the situations you can find yourself in. I didn't do a second playthrough for a long time, but it's worth it for some different endings. None of the endings are really "the good ending". They're all a bit open-ended, and all have something about them that you'll have to leave behind. The story is enjoyable; definitely interesting and unique enough to keep you engaged. I like to think that this takes place in some female-oriented alternate dimension of harry potter, what with the whole magical wizard school and professor Grabineer*cough*snape*cough*. But it has enough of its own story elements to set it apart from the universe that it drew much of its inspiration from. The main character is a little bit generic, but you're given enough of your own choices to project your own character onto her. My only real gripe is that you're character alludes to parents and a backstory at several points, but her parents are mostly left blank. Although I do have this theory that the school directors hypnotized them with magic to think that you just went off to boarding school... I mean, it really makes sense, and feels like it's hinted at a couple of times. I digress. The game is great to play with a friend for shits and giggles, as well as for a couple of serious playthroughs alone. I think all of my friends have played at least halfway through this game when we got bored, and I've played it multiple times, so I feel I definitely got my money's worth.

In short, best game ever 10/10. Buy it or yur a fagit.

12228045.review:
This is a wonderful and well written visual novel type game that is actually affected by your day to day choices. The world has a deep plot with lots of lore, multipul playthroughs only have some content overlap with each other. This is my absolute favorite game of this genre; all of the characters are believable, decisions actually matter and frequently have consequences one way or the other, and the exams are fun! There are a large number of different ways to beat the exams which is very satisfying so you can focus on different types of magic.

Graphics can put some people off with their Anime-ish style but they add a certain spice to the world that I think adds to the magical nature of the world. They are not fantastic but they are by no means awful and there are quite a few options in terms of hair style and color and eye shape and color. 11778499.review:
If I would have to summarise Magical Diary in one word I'd choose: Magical.

Glad I don't have to use just one word. Magical Diary is a mix between a Visual Novel, a Role-Playing, a Dating and a Puzzle game. You play (or are) a female student in a Magic School. You can customise your player character pretty well, especially considering it is a Visual Novel, mostly. You can choose a general body type, hair type, hair colour, eye colour, skin colour, etcetera.

Your days are partly spend studying a type of Magic (or activity) which you choose at the start of each week and specific events (influenced by choices and responses). On the weekend you have a variation of activities to pick from. This cycle basically repeats through out the game. Every few weeks there'll be a test, which consist of a first person puzzle you'll have to get through with the Magic (or skills) you've learned. In other words you're living through a normal school life... well, normal, except for the Magic, Demons, etcetera. This of course... includes dating! There's a few different candidates, both male and female to choose from: each with their own story and choices within that story. So there's replay value there if that's high on the priority list.

It took me roughly six hours to finish my first play-through. Second lasted about four. All in all an enjoyable experience.

11755262.review: A little bit RPG, a little bit school sim, and a dash of dating sim drawn together with an anime art style. Look out Hogwarts, the U.S.A. has its own school of magic. You take on the role of a female protagonist starting her first year in this visual novel style game. Basically, this is a Choose Your Own Adventure or Fantasy Fighting type of experience. I have a few of those game books and they are generally designed to defeat you. Magical Diary, on the other had, was more of a laid back experience and one I'm more likely to spin back up to try out the different branches that are offered. I had fun playing this and wouldn't mind seeing a sequel so that I can start my junior year.

11624613.review:
I really liked this game. Its my first graphic novel type game at least from what I can remember and I have not played any others yet although I do want to in the future. What I am getting at here is that I really have nothing to compare this game to so my review may seem a bit to positive but oh well I think it deserves it. So this game is about a girl that was told that she was a witch and that she could, if she chose to, go to a magical school. She then goes to class meets people and lives her one year at the school in which the game ends with here dating someone or the other multiple endings.. or you might just screw up and get expelled before school finishes. The game did really well opening up the magical world to you without hammering you down with uneeded explanation at the start. You basically learn about the world as you go along. The relationships for the most part felt real and were not to over the top romantic which allows you to get much more involved with the characters I find. The game had a lot of story lines and a lot of your choices effected how that storyline would go. I have replayed this game many times and still havn't uncovered every storyline part. I know this because I still have not unlocked all the achievements yet. So the game can easily be replayed many times. The game is also pretty short so that also makes it easier to replay. 

Umm there not really any huge issues with the game, i guess after replaying the game a few times you will get a lot of scenes that you have seen before, especially at the start, but you can quickly skip over those if you want to. I remember reading some one elses review saying that the game was to short and that it was only one year of school. I dont know if this is an issue for me really because if the game was longer than I think the replay value would probably lower so good job developers with making the game short. Maybe the developers can make a second game. Thats always a possibility I guess.

Una Visual novel clásica. Eres alumna de un colegio de magia y debes terminar el curso.

La historia es sencilla, pero por suerte tendremos bastante libertad y existen en el juego bastantes posibilidades. Desde como personalizamos a nuestra bruja, que magia aprende y cual no hasta por supuesto a quien nos ligamos y a quien mandamos a jugar al solitario a casa.

Algo particular de esta VN poco común en el genero (NO especifico) es que podemos tener una relación con personajes del mismo sexo. Solo con mujeres, ya que solo podemos jugar con un personaje femenino.

Tambien hay una posibilidad (no diré con quien para no spoilear) de tener una relación con alguien de mayor edad que nuestra protagonista. Y por mayor edad me refiero a unos 20 años o algo así. Bueno, para gustos colores.

Durante la historia nos encontraremos con unos "examenes" que son bastante sencillos y entretenidos de resolver pero que por desgracia puede que no podamos solucionar si no aprendimos los hechizos adecuados antes.

Si os gustan las Visual Novel más centradas en situaciones cotidianas que en el avance de una historia y os gusta que haya posibilidad de romance en ellas, os recomiendo totaltente Magical Diary.

This is quite a good game. If you've ever wanted to feel like Harry Potter, this is definitely the game for you. There are many interesting characters to befriend and some whom you can take the relationship a little farther. The magical spell you learn come in handy for many different situations, which is probably the best feature in this game. The school setting is mostly fantastic, as you get to plan your whole schoolyear and there are numerous fun school events. I also really dug my female character! It's hard sometimes to feel for someone of the opposite sex, but I was caught up in all her struggles and triumphs.

I do have a couple gripes about this game. For one, there are only two teachers, so the school feels very empty in that regard. My biggest complaint is the ending or maybe just the lack of a central story. I was very entertained throughout the game, but when I got to the end, it didn't feel like I actually accomplished much. I got some good grades, I got a boyfriend, and I got some merits. But that was about it. I was hoping the merit system would lead to something, but it was barely used. When the school year ended, I was fully expecting to continue my skill learnging the next year and be able to do something great with them, but the game just ended. There just didn't seem to be much of a point to all I did that year. There is a sequel on the way, so maybe my complaints will be remedied when the story continues. Here's hoping it will.

I really did enjoy the game for the most part so I'll give it 

8/10

I found the exams most difficult because you needed certain spells to be able to pass them, sure there's more than one way to pass but its hard to get your spell level high enough for the spells you need. I have now played it again, getting together with Virginia's prankster brother Donald who I actually think is a much better guy than Damien but Damien's storyline is much more unexpected and interesting. 11291749.review:
While there are similarities to Japanese-style visual novels, this one is basically a Harry Potter knock-off.  That said, I really enjoy it.  There are a lot of different storylines to follow, depending on the choices you make in the game.  If you aren't interested in reading (because it IS a visual novel) and don't like choose-your-own-adventure style games, you won't enjoy this.

For those who do, it's an entertaining story about your character, a 16 year old girl who discovers she is magical and goes off to magic boarding school.  Yes, it's Harry Potter-esque, but it has a pretty rich history.  Five colors of magic, lots of rules and oaths...  I was really interested in the storyline.  There are multiple endings, depending on whether you make certain choices.  You can romance several characters, both male and female, or befriend them - each offering more pieces of the entire story.  You'll have to play through several times to find out what truly happens with various situations in the game.

It's not as deep as Hanako's other game (Long Live the Queen - which I also enjoy), but I loved the characters.  My breath caught in my throat on a few scenes.  I only wish I could get more backstory on the world that is created within the game!

11272310.review: This game is adorable, absolutely adorable. Its only flaw is that it only goes through the one school year. The exams are actually quite fun, trying out spells and combinations. 11135431.review: Light-hearted but mature and most of all fun. 11122957.review:
This visual novel has an interesting and at times gripping storyline, has many interesting and relatable characters. But hardly has any time to develop on themas the campaign is so brutally short. Your first run through will last about 4 hours in real time. Which is far too little, regardless of the somewhat limited replayability. I would expect a minimum of 20+ hours and even then I might have een disappointed. 

The game has multiple endings but after your first there's very little drive to go back and replay every ending unless you saved periodically after every somewhat major choice in the game. Otherwise you'll be forced to drudge through the first 30 minutes of gameplay you've completed already. That's not fun at all. 

Another complaint would be that the game has no 'real ' endings. Every ending leaves you expecting something else to happen and you're left with little resolution. Which isn't a satisfying end for me. I would have een much happier if the game ran through the full 4 years, instead of the first year, which was mostly spent building relationships with characters and finding your click.

In conculsion, the game has an interesting and grippign storyline with many relatable, interesting characters. But falls flat because of the brutally short campaign, no sense of resolution in any ending and relatively high price point. If the game is on a 50% off or more sale I would recommend picking it up for a short but sweet story. Other than that, I see no reason to pick this game up for £10.99, when there are much longer and more gripping visual novels available.

Magical Diary is very cute, not too long, but lacks in options. Despite the lack of romance choices/ variation it is a good little game that's kept me entertained for a very long time. The stories for each path are okay, slightly fanatical, but then again what can you expect? There's consequences for actions that will either block out one romance path or open a new one, so it's tricky with it's choices. The stats you get from attending classes, from what I can see, don't effect your oprions, but do effect your tests, which lead to different paths depending on your results.

10955471.review:
This game really scratched my Harry Potter itch, I got it on a humble bundle sale, I forgot how long time ago, I never played it because lets be honest... Magical Diary? Female protagonist? Visual novel? When am I gonna get time in my busy schedule of playing hardcore action rpgs to try this game out? 

Well one day I told myself to give every game in my library a shot for 10 mins. So I play the game. Why not make a cute girl while I'm at it? There is decent amount of character customization. I'm happy with my character and I start the game. Bleah,  this is a lot like Harry Potter, unoriginal much?...  - 10 min later - This game is a lot like Harry Potter, this is amazing! 

You got your unique characters, magical holidays and traditions, spells to learn and use in challenges, secrets to unlock, you can follow your own path, the people you befriend help you later on, and the people you cross will remember you for it, balance your magical school work with occasions to make trouble. The story was amazing, cliche? Maybe. Fun and involving? Definitely. You can avoid interactions you do not want, of course there are unskipable events in the game, but I never felt I was being forced on a specific path at any point while playing. There are funny moments, romantic moments and tragic ones, my first ending was... unhappy to put it mildly, it made me stop playing so I can curl up on the bed and be drenched in sadness (I am a 24 year old male).

My only problems with this game are:
- the lack of teachers in Iris Academy, there are 2 people... that's it! No nurse, no janitor, no groundskeeper, no porter, no lunch lady, no coach, just 2 teachers. One of them apparently is the headmistress/ janitor/ doctor/ night watchman/ school councilor AND teaches 3 classes, as far as I can tell said 3 classes happen at the same time.
- the game is kinda pricey for it's length, buy it on a sale
- because of the multiple endings there can be no direct sequel to this title, but there will be a another game with a parallel story in the same setting.

TL;DR Great fantasy visual novel, its few problems don't get in the way of enjoying the game.

10931107.review:
На удивление ламповая новелла с не совсем ординарным подходом к сюжету. Перед нами не лихо закрученный рассказ с неожиданными поворотами, а что-то наподобие slice-of-life в хогвардских реалиях. И без взрослого Гарри Поттера с синдромом депресняка и сексуальной лихорадкой, что тоже очень ценно.

Правда, я прошел игру всего один раз, отвечая на вопросы как душе угодно, но игра не свернула к обязательной для многих "трагической завязке" (то, ради чего или против чего герои обычно борятся), а продолжила свой методичный и няшный поход до самых титров (хотя, наверняка, можно обострить наше "приключение", если выбирать определенные варианты). То есть я просто пошел в магическую школу, завел там друзей, узнал много нового, иногда попадал в незначительный просак, а потом учебный год закончился. И все. 

Чрезвычайно мило, расслабляюще и ни к чему не обязывающе. Рекомендую всем, кто хочет усесться поудобнее с чаем и печеньками и хоть ненадолго, но побыть юным волшебником в няшном мире. Без заморочек.

10924939.review:
I am not into anime and I never went near games like this (visual novels/dating sims) before because I just assumed they were designed for guys (especially the characters) and on that basis I wouldn't like it... but I got this in a bundle, tried it out and really REALLY enjoyed it!

It's a lot of fun and I found the characters and my own player character very relatable which is something I didn't expect from an anime-style game. This game literally changed my tastes in gaming.

As for the game itself; you play as a 16 year old witch (you can only play as a female) who starts her first year at a magic school where you learn and practice spells, perform school duties and form relationships with your classmates... and teachers if you're that unlucky... :p

It's just a shame the game ends after a few hours with so many spells and items I didn't get to use... I would love to see a Magical Diary 2nd Year game that lets you import your character over from the first one!

10914787.review:
This game is great if you're looking for something that you can replay over and over for multiple story lines, good characters, and interesting plots. There are five romanceable characters that are interesting and have depth--this is where replaying the game over and over comes in, because you won't be able to explore the story lines of all the characters or get to know them very well with just one play through! The game also features a magic system which is based off of different colors (No good vs evil or anything like that). You decide what magic you learn by going to different classes that you choose to go to or not. You could literally spend an entire week just resting. It's all up to you. The tests that you go through are held in dungeons and progressively get more challenging, but not so challenging that you would need outside help from a website to help you figure it out. Just simply save before you start an exam, and you should be fine.

Overall, the game is very well rounded for a dating sim.

10876248.review:
Magical Diary is a nice and medium big Visual Novel of the Otome section.
That means you get to play as a girl only.  
( For the boys: If you are realy tired of Otome games on steam: In this one you can unlock Yuri (lesbian) endings wit both Roommates.)

The game is a mix out of RPG and Visual Novel which means that you get during the game a huge amount of spells from your study sessions and you might have to use some of them during the exam dungeons.
I Said "might some of them" because you learn tons of spells but you actually just use about 5-6 of them.

However: It just feels better to get tons of spells as a Mage and not just the ones you definetly get to use, doesn't it?
Also you can complete the dungeons with a variety of possibilities, there is nowhere only one way to do it.

A realy nice feature is that you are able to design your Character with a tool so everyones heroine might look somewhat different. Also the items you can buy at the Mall will be visibaly seen on the character. For example if you buy her a star wand your avatar will hold a starwand if equiped. That also gives a nice variety of appearances.

One Walkthrough takes about 6-7 hours which is quite the medium length of a visual Novel. 
If you are planing on getting all achievements it takes about 12 hours as much as i have playtime (probably a bit less if you are english native speaking or just a faster reader, i might as well was a few minutes of those afk)
With all the achievements you have NOT finished all the routes but only 2-3 from the huge amount of routes possible.

Extra achievements for all routes like in most dating sim novels would have been nice.. (for example "unlock the romantic ending of Ellen, Damien and so on) [in case a developer reads this: Could it be possible to create those achievements?    *holding a puppy next to the developers which looks with wide open and extremely cute eyes to the mod/dev*


I realy enjoyed reading this Novel and do not regret getting it, although i got it in a humble bundle a while ago i would have payed full price for it if i hadn't already gotten it. Bought a copy for a friend as well when it was on sale.


 ~9 - 9.5/10  i would say probably

10850957.review:
All right, let's be honest: this is a life/dating sim of a spontaneously American magical girl at a magical boarding school. You want every stupid trope or blatant reference to magical schools? It has them in SPADES, from magical sorting to uniforms to stereotyped professors to every kind of magical creature under the sun. I got this during the summer sale, so I had no qualms about burning a little over $5 CAD on this.

Once you shove all that aside, Magical Diary does have some depth to it. Play your cards right, and a character that you ignored on your first playthrough might reveal the reasons for their weirdness. Everyone has a backstory with a twist, and I like that kind of mystery: it gives the game some replay value.

Flaws: obvious rip from obvious references, the magic system is meh, graphics are cut-and-paste, easy to fail if you have no idea what you're doing on the first go but really easy to pass everything after. This is [b]not[/b] everyone's cup of tea, but it's cute and a little different if you're into life/dating sims.

I really enjoyed this game, honestly. Yeah, the visuals can be a bit underwhelming, and yes, it's essentially Anime Harry Potter Starring A Girl, but the story's fun and the characters are really likable. (And there's a twist in one of the romance paths which honestly shocked me, although that could just be down to my inexperience with this genre.) 

The school mechanics - choosing what classes you go to, which in turn influences what kind of magic you specialise in - are fun too, but don't really have an effect on the outcome of the story beyond dictating what choices are available to make during the dungeon-crawl exam portions. 

In short, if you've got a couple of hours to kill and ever wanted to visit American Hogwarts, this is the game for you!

10775526.review:
In this game, my character got into a long term abusive relationship with a demon. Then I started over and seduced my sporty roommate. It's like a bad Harry Potter fanfic-- even when they're talking about hazing, or completely misunderstanding the definition of "consent" in some creepily metaphoric soul-stealing ritual (And seriously, Professor McGonagall-alike? Because I said "yes", even though it was all under false pretenses, that makes it okay? WRONG.)

If you actually, you know, want to play a visual novel with a deeply affective plot that lets you make difficult decisions, you'll probably want to look somewhere else. If you want to fiddle around with a few different storyline paths in a Harry Potter-like environment, then this might be for you.

Just... don't go into this looking for depth, sanity, or healthy relationships-- but if you just want to date someone with wings, campaign for student council on a platform that'd make any Dark Lord proud, and generally baffle at the insanity of your character's decisions, this is not a horrible game.

5/10, wouldn't date demon again.

Overall, it's an entertaining, light-hearted story with a huge variety of choices and endings. You can tell the developers spent a lot of time writing this!

Magical Diary is made by the same group that made Long Live the Queen: if you liked one, you'll like the other.

Basically, Magical Diary is a Hogwarts Simulator and Long Live the Queen is a Sansa Stark Simulator.

They're not terribly expensive and they're fun-short games with a lot of character interactions that move between foreground and background depending on your choices.

For example, there's one day where Donald will try to prank Virginia with magical horse dung.  If you happen to be coincidentally in the dorm when he comes to leave the prank, you can convince him - amoung other things - to write a letter claiming it is a gift from her senior initiation leader (who's really into druid things).

I definitely think it should be played with a friend for the sake of shenanigans.

10058838.review:
I don't suppose there is much to say about this game that hasn't been said already, but I just have to leave it a good review.  It's an amazing game!
Magical Diary is a Visual Novel with RPG elements.  You play as a new girl at a magical school, and must balance your academic, social and romantic lives as best you can!  There are exams you must pass, which are one of my favourite parts of the game.  You can use the spells you have learnt in class to solve the puzzles set to you in various ways.  I wish there were more of these chances to use magic, really!
There are several possibilities for romance.  I've only followed one through so far, but it was very emotional and moving.  I think I am in love with him XD  There appear to be female options as well as male, so I will probably go this way on my second playthrough.  It is always nice when a game caters to different tastes in this way.
It's shorter than many visual novels; I was a little surprised at how suddenly it ended.  It took me about 4 hours to play through once.  This is easy to forgive though - the game features far more choices and branches than most visual novels.  That means it has a lot of replay value, and if you're anything like me you'll definitely want to play again!
The doesn't have the difficulty of Long Live the Queen, which allows you to sit back and enjoy the story without worrying too much, unless you are striving for all the achievements!  The exams offer a fun challenge which you can take at your own pace.  It is fun to find many different ways to solve the same puzzle.

You just choose what classes to go to, click on a conversation choice here and there, and show up for your tests. You can quickly pass these if you google the answer, because there is otherwise no skill required. If you got it in a bundle, play it once. Otherwise, it gets a skip from me.

I found Magical Diary to be a whimsical and slightly addicting little story game. It has tremendous replay value, due to numerous story paths. The game allows you to create a female main character, with few anime style options. It proceeds to drops you into a one year stint as a freshman student in a magical academy. During this time, you interact with various characters, almost all of which can become love interests (male and female alike). The characters are interesting and the romances are endearing.You learn spells and use them in highly limited capacity for very specific events. The most important events would be the exams. You can pass the exams with various spell combinations or simply decide to surrender and fail.

I did enjoy this game for what it was. However, I do wish it had been longer. I would also have welcomed more use for the many spells that were learned.

9952081.review:
带着养成元素的美制日式文字冒险游戏（Galgame），制作组Hanako后来还开发了Steam上的Long Live The Queen，基本也是这个风格，本作的故事灵感源自哈利波特，麻瓜家庭（游戏中叫野种Wildseed）出生的女主玛丽苏（默认名就叫这个，作者用来自嘲玛丽苏式的展开，其实开始时可以自定义外貌和姓名）进入魔法学院学习，交朋友谈恋爱学魔法过考试，不过这里没有大魔王不用拯救魔法世界，更加注重日常的学习生活

系统上虽然看着有养成元素多么多么复杂，其实走线的时候用处不大，安排完日程后主要是通过带有隐藏好感机制的事件触发系统来决定进哪条线，和画面左边的那一大串数据并没有直接联系，游戏有五条主要的角色线，三男两女（可以攻略两个室友好评，百合才是真爱啊～）其中一个是老师（话说游戏中只出现了两个老师，偷懒），有一大堆同学不能攻略很怨念，一堆萌妹子完全是路人作者你到底是要哪样啊

那些数据除了点满可以出成就以外，主要是用来影响考试，Smart就是MP，Strength就是HP，Stress决定学习失败率，然后五色法系决定所习得咒语，基本都是以应用性法术为主，战斗在考试里也非常次要，过考试会用到特定的日用法术组合来解决谜题，其实这个系统开放度高想法非常棒，可惜考试就那么几次，而且日常中法术对主要剧情也没有影响（其实法术之外Smart和Cute之类的数据也会影响对话，但都说不上重要），大量听上去很帅气的法术根本没有用武之地

大概最重要的数据就是Merits了，除了影响部分事件的触发以外，还要注意千万不能到达-50，不然会送你一个成就然后女主被开除……除了一些事件以外，Merits主要通过通过考试来加减，不过即便平时考试全挂但不作死并且多想办法靠事件来加的话也是可以毕业的，反正目标仅仅是不被开除，学校没有成绩评级制度，放心走线就好

作为一个事件触发制的Galgame我感觉还是很有趣的，想法优秀剧情也不错，就是游戏只有一个学年比较郁闷啊（9月初入学经过两个学期4月底放假，美国学制），我想要第二第三第四学年啊，我要更多的考试来实践更多的法术啊，我要更多可以攻略的妹子啊，我还想要其它学院路线的外传啊——把我的钱拿去，作者你快把续作交出来！（可惜作者说暂时没有出第二部的想法，唉）

9941021.review: A terrific visual novel heavily inspired by Harry Potter (you're a new student at a magical academy with various houses, you take magical classes with one supportive and one obnoxious professor, your allies are a brain and a jock, etc.) Any lack of originality in the adherence to genre conventions is blown away by the quality of the gameplay, though. The time management segments are intuitive, there are multiple plotlines running through the story (many of which you only get vague hints of if you aren't involved), and the graphics are cute and charming. Your character is female; I counted two F/M options, one bisexual F/F option, one "questioning" F/F option, two secret options (both F/M), and one casual F/F encounter. It was also pleasant to see a game universe that defaults to Spivak pronouns (!) and doesn't make a big deal about queer relations.

9925562.review: For whatever reason, my brother has been trying to get me to play this game for months (he doesn't even like otome games???), and eventually bought it for me. At first I thought this was a Harry Potter rip-off (the magic, the Snape-like professor, the merits/point system), but this game had me pleasantly surprised. I'm now obsessed. So many storylines are going on at the same time, and it seems like everytime I start or load a new file I find several new events & endings. I love the magic exams- they are challenging and provide variety to the regular stat-building classes routine. I'm not wowed by the romantic options (the only character I liked turned into a crazy ass psycho, yet I can't hate the developer for making such a creative twist) but I would still recommend this to any otome game fan. It's fun, it's interesting, it's original, and it's pretty funny. I am convinced the developer is a genius mastermind- I want to buy all their games now.

9922407.review:
Magical Diary
Was soll ich dazu sagen, außer: SUPER.

Aber nun mal zu einer genaueren Bewertung:

Bilder:
Die Bilder sind allesamt sehr schön gezeichnet und lassen sich wunderbar anschauen. Die Charactere strahlen alle ein gewisses Etwas aus und man fühl allein durch ihren Ausdruck, was sie gerade denken. 


Charaktere:
Es sind viele verscheidene Charaktere, welche alle (wirklich alle der Hauptcharaktere) ihre eigenen Geheimnisse und Macken haben, welche es zu ergründen gilt. Kein Charakter gleich dem anderen und jeder ist gut durchdacht. Die Geschichten sind schlüssig und man kommt sich nicht so vor, als ob einem hier nur Stereotypen vorgesetzt wurden.


Story/Wiederspielbarkeit:
Die Geschichte entpuppt sich als enorm abwechslungsreich. Die Eigentliche Hauptstory zieht sich immer entlang der Prüfungen und mancher fester Ereignisse, die sich im Laufe des Schuljahres ereignen. Doch was um diese Ereignisse drumherum passiert und wie viel man über die Hintergründe bestimmter Vorfälle erfährt, dass hängt ganz von der aktuellen Spielweise ab und vor allem auch stark von der eingeschlagenen Romanze.
Und diese Romanzen sind es auch, weswegen man das Spiel einfach mehrfach spielen MUSS. Spätestens ab dem Weihnachtsevent entwickelt sich in jedem Pfad ein ganz eigener Handlungsstrang, welcher ganz neue Informationen über z.B. Ereignisse preis gibt, die man mit anderen Charakteren nie erfahren hätte. So wechselt sich eine Szenerie von ganz normal und harmlos plötzlich zu komplett absurd und lebendsgefährtlich. Und all das durch ein paar unterschiedliche Entscheidungen des Spielers.


Alles in allem kann ich dieses Spiel jedem empfehlen, wer nicht Wert auf ein actiongeladenes sondern auf ein sehr gut erzähltes und nicht minder spannendes Abenteuer legt. Dieses Spiel gehört schon jetzt zu meinen Favouriten.

9778878.review:
While most visual novels intended for females hit you over the head with romance and pretty boys, this game actually takes this idea and almost puts it as a side note. Don't get me wrong, your relationships will be a major plot point however you also need to manage your friendship with your two roommates as well as the role you play in school. You might be treasurer and have to help plan events, or be part of a club designed to seek revenge on others. 

Of course, your love interest still does play a point in the game. You can date either a male or female or even a Professor if you go down the right path. What makes this game great is how it developes the relationships. Your character is not swept off her feet instantly but the first cute face. Each relationship feels realistic and is built on many layers. You even get quite a bit of back story to each character you date (save for one bonus Steam added relationship which is a secret bonus one added to the Steam version of the game). But don't think you can't get dumped at any time by your SO. Pick the wrong options and it's back to the single life. 

Of course since there's magic in the game and you're going to school, you do take exams where you use a few spells and common sense to solve the problems in a dungeon that is a screen by screen styled place (aka it's not a free roaming thing but you move from one screen to the next like a hidden object game without the hidden objects).

It's really nice to have your own PC (playable character) have internal conflict as well with her family so you get some character developement as well.

Overall, I've put over 10 hours into a graphic novel game and I read fast. There are so many paths to go down and things to do differently in each run through that the replay value is super high. It's a very interesting game which incorporates a lot of different aspects into one wonderful game.

9760897.review:
Even though this game has some good characters and the gameplay is quite fun, the fact that it is so abusive towards women makes me unable to recommend it. 



Good:

+ You get to chose how your character wants to respond in the story and it allows you to avoid certain situations.
+ Fastforward option that speeds through any previous dialog you have read. 
+ There is some customization to your character, with name and appearence. 
+ Ability to save and quit the game at any time.
+ Soundtrack is good, I enjoyed the tune that played when people were mischivious. 


Bad:

~ Dungeon Exams ~

Every now and then, the girl you play gets an exam where she is put in the same generic looking dungeon and has to use her magic and smarts to find a way out of it. And there are so many problems with these exams that they are unenjoyable to play through.

- You have to have certain magical skills or you can't complete them. This is not told by the game or what skills you need. 
- 98% of your spells are useless. This leads to the same problem I had with ”Cthulu saves the world”, where you have to constantly scroll through useless spells to find the ones you need. It also leads to a lot of frustration as the spells really give you no idea what to use instead.
- Your magical points are extremely limited. I failed one of the dungeons because I missclicked where I wanted to place an object. Ugh. 
- Some dungeons I have quite frankly never been able to figure out what to do. They look too samey and there really isn't any indication of what they expect you to do. If you fail, the professor yells at you to study what the solution is. But you are never given the option to actually study it.

If it wasn't for these dungeons, I may have recommended the game, because the fastfoward option let's you play around with the story as much as you want. But instead you get stuck in these tedious dungeons. 

~ Abusive relationships ~

I am not sure which age group this game is for, but this has a huge red warning flag about what message it sends to women and young girls. Any male-female romance you can persue in the game is always aimed towards ”If I love him enough, then I can change him and he will love me back.” and some of them are emotionally and psysically abusive. I see these kinds of stories a lot when the girl is forced into being ”saved” by the ”bad boy”, which should make her eternally grateful to him, while he continues abusing her until her love makes him ”kind”. 

To give some examples of what kind of abuse the 16 year old girl has to take, some of them includes murder attempt (I am not kidding), being pushed and held against a wall, yelled at, blamed for things she didn't do, threatened, lied to, strung along, forced to give up her friends for him... the list goes on. 2 of the 3 possible male-female relationships are 90% abusive. What were they thinking? 
One of these relationships you get forced into based on bizarre circumstances, where then the character literally owns you and will continously abuse you as he is unhappy with you. 

There are also some girl-girl relationships, but the only reason I haven't tried them out is simply because I didn't find the female characters interesting. Maybe I will when I can force myself through the tedious dungeons again.

9760099.review:
Yeah. This is a game called Magical Diary.
Is there a diary in the game? Yes. Is there magic? Yes. Is the diary a Magical Diary? ...no, actually. I guess the author needed a title and Magical Diary was just as generic as they could get.
I mean, you can read the diary. Maybe it writes itself or something, but it doesn't do anything special aside from that, if it is the case. It just tells you what you already know. It's useful to see what happened if you haven't played the game in a while, for sure.
But yeah, despite the incredibly generic title, the also somewhat generic art style (you know, the type of art that middle-school girls and boys draw when they want to draw manga characters (actually, the settings aren't bad, just the character portraits, but there's like 10 settings in total...)) the story is actually pretty unique.
It doesn't really pander, it isn't light, there are routes that simply don't have a good end, no matter how hard you try, just because that's how they SHOULD be. It doesn't indulge a teenage girl's fantasy of going to a magical school (well, to some extent. It isn't a perfect world.)
You would expect "Magical Diary" to be some wet fantasy like Twilight, but it has its moments where little choices have a bigger impact.

Also, this isn't just a straight up visual novel. It IS a game, it DOES have puzzles, and while short, it can be a challenge.
You CAN lose. Heck, I survived, but I didn't feel like I had a "good" route, aside from being a fairly adept sorceress by the end.

Get this game. If you like visual novels, get this game. If you like those old interactive stories that you rarely see anymore, get this game.

If you don't wanna spend 15 bucks or whatever it costs in your country, wait for a sale. I doubt you'll be disappointed if you've liked a VN before.

9735395.review:
There is way more than meets the eyes about this game. 
While it IS a visual novel greatly inspired by the Japanese games of the same category, it is not "only" a dating sim. You can shape your own path, your own life. On my first playthrough I decided to let things unfold without really trying. I decided to trust my instincts and I thought the game was shallow, empty, predictive... 
Oh how WRONG I was. I though for sure this game was "pretty little lady perfect love story" and I found myself in a pretty dire and serious situation. Just "being good girl" and "Acting with kindness and love" will actually kill you. 
On my second playthough, I changed only one answer... and got a whole new story. As soon as you make a choice, including which classes to take or not to take, you unlock new possibilities... and lose some. In this game's world, a witch's word is taken literaly, seriously. If you ask something you will be forever bound by those words. I was unsure at first about this facet of the game. It was on my fourth playthrough that I finally realised the actual depth of the game.

Not only can we shape our story, but we can also change the way the game plays. We can change the way every character sees us. We can change the game's world to its very core. And that is something I love. If you think this game is Linear, you simply did not try the other answers. Just so you know, there is 4 ways to unlock the "Soul nibble" (5 if you count the rescue scene) and over a dozen to remove it completly from the game. You have many choice, use them wisely... or do like me and mess everything up just for the giggles.

Last word? I am the worst wife in existence.

9704338.review:
A lot of fun and somewhat surreal. A nice cross between an RPG and a storybook.  Puzzles, romance, comedy, it's all there. I thoroughly recommend it.

Gameplay type: Stats based visual novel
Premise: Hogwarts dating sim. Seriously. You are a ‘wildseed’ (basically a muggle, you’re a witch that sprung up in the wild rather than being cultivated from a magical family), embarking on your first year at magic school. You meet a collection of interesting characters and can choose to romance them. Each week you have to choose which magic classes to go to (they’re all taught by one of two teachers, who must have mastered the ability to be in two places at once…) each class raises your stat in that magic type. Every so often you have to take exams which test your skills (basically you get put in a dungeon and have to use the various spells you’ve unlocked to puzzle solve your way out). 
Representation: Lesbian romance options. 
Replayability: Fair. The different choices you make and different romances you choose make a difference in how the game unfold. Since all exams have multiple ways to solve, there is incentive to focus on different magic types to see how things play out. 
Other thoughts: You can marry Snape. (He’s not called Snape, but that’s who he is). You are 16 and you can wind up married to your teacher. This is treated as some wacky shenanigan, not something to be really concerned about. To his credit he does not take advantage of this situation. The game also contains an emotionally abusive romance option. You CAN get a happy ending with this, but it is not easy, and if you fail you get some of the few bad endings in the game. Interestingly your relationship with your roommates/friends is crucial to success in this game.

9703700.review:
Magical Diary is the best proper roleplaying game that came out in 2012. It is now 2017, the sequel is nowhere in sight, and I still stand by this. Magical Diary is beautfiul, brave, interesting and full of personality and choice.

And I absolutely mean this unironically. There is an amazing sense of character and depth to your choices, skills and spells you bring with you, and the storyline becomes quite amazing in a mostly non-camp way. Yes, there's a sexy guy with demon wings and a grumpy teacher who maybe isn't that bad, and more school conspiracies than you can shake your wand at - but surprisingly, this all makes for a very smooth and immersive ride where choices really matter.

Fleshing out the story are several mini-challenges in form of dungeon runs - and challenge you they will, with proper multiple solutions based on both what spells you have learned so far and your personal player smarts.


Buy this if you have any love for roleplaying games done right, and don't allow yourself to be put up by the anime graphics and the wizard high school setting. You will not regret this purchase.

9698441.review:
I got this game as part of a Humble Bundle. Surprisingly enough, it is less weird/girly than it looks.

For my first playthrough, it felt similar to a rogue-like game such as Faster Than Light (with a lot more reading and plot than FTL). Although the dungeons are slightly randomized per playthrough, second and onward playthroughs will be a lot easier than the first, but there's enough plot to warrant at least a couple playthroughs beyond the first.

It's not the longest game ever, but it's not the shortest; it might take you between 2 and 5 hours for your first playthrough, depending on your reading speed. For what it's worth, I enjoyed Magical Diary more than I enjoyed The Stanley Parable.

A 4/5 rating wouldn't go amiss for this game; the major downsides is its relatively short length and "poor" graphics (they aren't poor, but rather underdeveloped. A bit more detail here and there wouldn't hurt).

strong = 50

9648856.review:
Magical Diary is a visual novel style strategy game akin to Long Live the Queen that is heavily inspired by Harry Potter fanfiction. You play as 'Mary Sue', a young wildseed (read: mudblood) witch who has entered a boarding school for magical folk to learn the craft. 

My initial impression of Magical Diary is not favourable. On the upside the anime-style character is very customizable, some of the background artwork is nice, and there seem to be a number of different narrative paths that you may take through the game with hints at mysteries to uncover, making for good replay value. On the downside much of the character art is amateurish, and the game does little to hide its fanfiction roots. Because of this you wind up with a narrative that is chock-full of cliches, making the story very predictable. The strategic gameplay also feels overwhelmed at times by the sheer amount of narrative exposition there is to read. It took me almost 30 minutes to get through 2 weeks' worth of decisions, when it should have taken 5 minutes at most. 

Bottom Line? This game will not appeal to everyone. If you enjoy reading Harry Potter fanfiction and love visual novel style games you may enjoy playing Magical Diary. Otherwise stay away.

9445822.review:
Magical Diary is adorable. 

When it comes to story, this game isn't original in the slightest, but that doesn't matter: It's riding on the wave of young adult fiction, namely Harry Potter's fantastical influence, but it does it well. Serious teen issues are generalized and explored in a way that's relateable. Characters fit stereotypes fairly stringently most of the game, but, depending how you play, they may be broken apart just past that surface level in a way that communicates social problems to youngsters.

It's nice for those reasons. It's nice for a lot of reasons, but it seems like the target audience is what will most likely get this game unfair negative attention (in addition to the really cheap-looking production values, even by visual novel standards).

Something this game does very well is CHOICE: The schedule of events and how differently the game can go based on what you do on certain days is mind-boggling. The sheer volume of stories that can *greatly* affect *your* life as a magic teenage girl is pretty incredible given the development cycle this game had.

First, I would really like to see a story based on a male protagonist. I liked this story and playing as a female character, but I missed the choice of gender. Second, if the gender choice is not possible, why not extent the story at least? I mean, right when I felt the story started getting awesome, the game finished. All in all, I recommend this game to fans of japanese school simulation games and visual novels. I don't know if the price is the best for what the game has to offer. It has huge replayability for sure, but the short extent of the story diminishes the quality in my eyes.

This game isn't terrible by any means, however I can't recommend it for people into stat based games. As a Visual Novel it's a bit marginal too, but not thumbs down territory.

Firstly, this game NEEDS a guide. If you don't have the correct spells at the correct times you WILL FAIL the exam. While the game tells you that you don't need to ALL the magical colors IT IS LYING.
THAT being said, you don't need all the colors up all the way, as a matter of fact 90% of the spells you get are completely useless. After certain time periods you can just stop leveling colors, like level Black Magic to 30 then just never put anything more into it. 
This is not a good design. It is not a design that gives you freedom. All of the puzzle have VERY SPECIFIC solutions and only just a few have optional ways to solve them.

The VN part. All of the male romance choices are annoying. The one you probably want "William" isn't getable due to him having a misogyny crisis. (He's bi, but he's sworn off women... I'm not sure that's how sexuality works. "Oh today I'm just not going to be attracted toooo WOMEN!"
The choices that are left are the Demon, The annoyance, the Snape Stand-in. 
The Demon is an easy route to screw up and lose on.
Donald the annoyance is just that. He's based on the Weasly twins.
Grabiner is the 'hates everyone' strict professor that I don't even think you can really [i]romance[/i] and need a certain event to actually "get" him.

The options for women are slightly more varied and less annoying:
Ellen, the softspoken bookworm who wants to avoid trouble
Virginia the "weird" outgoing and peppy one.

Basically people that care about you VS the trend in otome gaming of having abusive, annoying jerks.

8811626.review:
Magical Diary is a anime graphic novel roleplaying game set in a life and school simulation. This is a pretty specific genre, but surprisingly there's some competition. 

After playing through Magical Diary I cannot give it a recommendation. Compared to games like Academagia and Long Live the Queen, Magical Diary is has a story that's too linear, gameplay that's too simplistic, and RPG mechanics that are too shallow. It might be good for younger audiences, but for those who enjoy the challenge of life simulators in a graphic novel RPG experience - this game just isn't going to cut it. 

I hope that the developer produces a second year sequel to this title and addresses these concerns. If so, I'll come back and edit this review with a qualified recommendation. Until then, play one of Magical Diary's superior competitors instead.

8726473.review:
If you enjoy the simulation genre, then I recommend picking this up. My feelings are mixed about the game, but you will probably get a good laugh out of it anyways. I've put a lot of hours into this game and replayed it a bunch and have enjoyed it each time. 

[h1]PROS[/h1]

[*]  Variety of choices about spells, activities, which person you'd like to romance, etc. Many of the cut scenes and events also give you options. 

[*] Replayability. The game isn't very long, but becuase there are so many choices, you may find yourself wanting to play again.. just to see what it is that you could do differently. 

[*]  Light sense of humor, sort of funny, a little bit disturbing, and even a little bit romantic.

[*]  You're not bound to date only boys. You can date women, or nobody at all. It doesn't define what relationships are right and wrong, and so that's sort of nice to see. Hell, you're not really pressured to have a relationship at all. 

[*] The font is easy to read. Which is good, because that's mostly what you'll be doing in this game. 

[*] You can basically marry Snape. So, there's that. 

[h1]CONS[/h1]

[*]  The game IS short. If you don't find interest in the game and don't feel like replaying it, then it may not be worth your money for the few game play hours that you'll get out of it. 

[*]  You can only play as a female. Character customization is also very limited. 

[*] The artwork is pretty crude. The characters look like they've all been done in Paint. 

[*]  The music. This is probably one of the things I hated most about this game. There were only four (I think) different songs/tunes that play depending on the event or what you're doing, and they loop. There really wasn't a lot of creativity or anything put into that I feel, and it gets on your nerves after awhile. 

[*]  You'll need to play the game multiple times to unlock all of the different achievements, if that's your thing. So again, if you're not interested, that may suck if you're a completionist. There is also a pretty large room for error if you haven't researched/played the game before, so it can be frustrating if you're trying to reach a certain goal.  

[*]  No voice overs. Nothing is voiced in this game, so you'll have to read everything. I mean, it is a point and click simulator so a lot of reading and clicking is expected, but voices may have helped give a little bit of life to the characters. 

[*]  No "new game+". It would be nice to be able to keep your money or some of your clothing items when you go to start a new game. It would help make things a bit easier, and speed up additional playthroughs.

I picked this game up when it went to sale, it was a measly $5 off, but I was interested. The child in me adored the animae feel to it so I purchased it.
As much as i enjoy the games style. It gives you an option just about all games like this have. Choice. The power of choice in a game it strong, which I believe is why The Stanly Parable did so well, but I suppose thats off topic. While the game gives you choice, the slightest move in the begining might give you the exact same ending, even if what you do after is completely different. There are few endings that surround 4 characters in the story. That is a good amount but the game, being more of a story, is hard. You can aim for a specific character ending but chances are you will be kicked out ahead of time, or be with the person you didn't want. 
My main complaint is the tests. The game throws tests at you, and the game itself doesn't teach you what you need to be taught and many people (like myself) will not read the lessons and skip through them. The game gives you "Study Time" but doesn't give you the ability to study. I have played the game, possible 10 times and have been kicked out 9 times. I finished once by using a website to ensure I get the Damien ending.
The demerits you recieve in the begining, which you CAN'T PREVENT is what slowly brings me down. Plus, giving them in groups of five, while when you recieve 15 your kicked out, come on!
I know my complaint list is long, but I just ramble and go into detail. 
This game is incredibly long and is a game you can play over and over reaching different endings.

I very muchh enjoyed this game.

8654308.review:
My opinion on Magical Diary is mixed. On the one hand I had fun on my first playthrough. I wanted to see where the story was going. The RPG aspect (skills to grow mainly) seemed interesting. On the other hand after having finished the game twice, it seems that no matter what skills you choose to improve or how bad you do at the several “exams”, you can always finish the game, and it doesn’t change the story much.

Replayability is compromised by having to re-read everything or almost everything, or risking missing some new original developments in the story when you’ve taken different decisions in the past. If you enable to option to fast-forward then the game will not stop on new text that you haven’t read in your previous playthrough.

Still it was a nice experience the first time, so if you’re not afraid of reading relationships/magic stuff (the game, in retrospect, is more a visual novel than an RPG) and can get it on sale for cheap, then you could do worse than trying it.

8637751.review:
A unique addition to common dating sims! Magical Diary, unlike other games, contains bonus features including a chance to cast spells, use some point of strategy in dungeons, and with surprise events every other *game* week!

Although the puzzles aren't very difficult, they grow in level and, in the end, have many more 'dead' ends and less 'good' ends. Five merits are for basic answers whilst ten for greater ones, driving you to complete it in as many ways possible! The numerous amount of save slots allows 'stop', 'replay, 'stop', 'replay.

A downpoint in the game is that there are only female characters but this game is very loose in sexual orientation so you could be heterosexual, homosexual, or asexual. In fact, you can totally ignore the romance part of the game (though it's a gigantic, huge, overshadowing punch).

The art is beautiful and expressions are neat, character customization is limited but not non-existent (which, in many otome games, feature pre-generated avatars). The subplot is light but there and you could enjoy the ways the plot unravels.

However, despite all its positive points, I have many negative rulings for this game too;

8616094.review:
While the gameplay often leaves many elements very underutilized, this game on the whole is a worthwhile experience. It's a little like finding a bizarre Harry Potter fanfiction Choose Your Own Adventure while drunk: at first you feel like you shouldn't be enjoying the experience, but after a while you stop caring.

The game handles itself with a refreshing lack of gravity (the main character's default name is "Mary Sue," for gods' sakes), but some of the plotlines and relationships are remarkably smart, well-written affairs. In example, there's a character I will refer to as NotSnape. My character, a girl in her late teens, accidentally got married to NotSnape. I nearly bailed on the game right there, but what followed was a downright heartfelt relationship that did not shy away from how bloody creepy it was.

Some use of walkthroughs/guides is more or less required to see a lot of the content, but given the genre, I can't really hold that against it. I recommend this game, but don't pay too much for it; if it's on sale, give it a go. There's also an excellent demo available (whether on Steam or on the dev website, I forget) that one could try if on the fence.

8526217.review:
Magical Diary is another Japanese style interactive novel, with a bit of a twist. On top of the usual choice-conciquence system, there is an rpg style leveling system for several magical spell groups, and a rudimentary equipment system that makes changes to your character's image frame.

Graphically, the game is mostly what one expects from visual novels. Static backgrounds of middling quality, and somewhat more animated frames for characters. The main character can be customized, and you can go shopping for equipment that further affects the visuals. The anime style artwork is unpolished, but its easy enough to get over. The music and sounds are fine. Of course, in visual novels the most important part of design is the story. In Magical Diary, the story is okay. Its nothing exceptional, but there are several branches available allowing for at least several unique playthroughs.

Technically, the game is fine. The RPG elements work well for the environment its in, the menus do the trick, and overall the system is simple enough to handle easily.

Overall, this game is pretty okay. Its nothing exceptional, but if you enjoy a storytelling experience with a higher degree of interactivity than the usual visual novel, you will probably like Magical Diary.

If you found this review helpful, please have a look at [u][url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/essidus/recommended/]my other reviews.[/url][/u]

8509915.review:
Magical Diary is part point-and-click, part adventure, part RPG.

You play as a girl in her first year at a magical school. You'll spend this year studying magic, and wooing boys (and girls?), because what else would you do?

I was thoroughly entertained when playing Magical Diary. I found the characters to be mostly interesting, and was surprised at how much depth some of them have. I picked out the guy I wanted to get my magical paws on right away, and it took me the majority of the school year to break him down. Perseverance was key though, eventually I got that kiss!

The great thing about Magical Diary is the amount of possibilities I turned down in order to go down this route. This game has a lot of replayability as in the first two weeks of game time alone there are at least three distinctive massive plot-lines available if the right options are chosen.

The RPG elements come from learning the right subjects, and unlocking spells to use in dungeons. Dungeons are used as tests, and there are 5 or 6 of them in the game. They're not very impressive, but without them the lessons you learn and items you buy would be a pretty needless.

Overall, Magical Diary is a game that shouldn't be taken to seriously. It's a fun experience which is more story-play than gameplay.

Bottom line: A great way to spend a couple of hours. Solid writing.

8274876.review:
Why do I think MD is awesome? (Because I do think that.) There are plenty of things I COULD list, from being a fan of the maker, to the cute artwork, to the by turns adorable, dark, intense and thought-provoking stories told in the form of romantic paths, the the simple quality of the game. Oh, wait, I just listed them. Oh well.

My point was, what I really love, even after so many playthroughs, and so much more experience now of RPG and VisNovel games than I had when I first played it, is how it walks the line of complexity. Most VisNovels give you simple text, with choices that affect outcome. Simple, enjoyable, easy to figure out. Other games also incorporate a skill system that affects the outcome just as much, and can be fiendishly difficult to figure out - do you have enough charm to be with this character, and if you don't, do you have enough energy to build on it without your character burning out or starving? The combinations can be endless - or at least so numerous that it takes a true devout to get through them all.
Magical Diary, to me, is a perfect crossover. Because the magic system is complex, but straight-forward and, most importantly, it's in the game as a BONUS. Talk about replayability - when you're done with the romance routes and want to replay them, you can play around with your class shedule and skill levels to unlock some bonus content. And there's even a direct payoff to your skill building with the fun dungeons. The dungeon exam at the end of the terms might not change between playthroughs, but you, like the characters themselves, can have a lot of fun keeping your character from learning the spell for the obvious solution and really trying to think outside the box.

In short, whether you're in this for a cute, fun, deep VN, or a skill-builder with the occasional secret bonus that won't eat up weeks of your life or require a walkthrough, Magical Diary is something you should try out. I loved it when I first bought it and, unlike other VNs, I still love it now.

Otherwise, it's solidly written, has both lady and dude romance options (or none at all as you prefer), and some awright situations. It's cozy with just a little edge. You know who you are.

7924192.review:
'Magical Diary' is a cool simulation game. You play a girl during her first year in magic school. The idea in the game is to make friends, get along with your teachers, solve some puzzles (exams to be solved with magic), and maybe get a boyfriend or even get married. 

There are quite a lot of options to explore, so beating the game once isn't all there is to it. I've gone through three different branches, although one of them ended prematurely, as it was my first game and I didn't bother to read any of the instructions or guidelines, so I got myself expelled from school and didn't get far.

The graphics aren't anything special, but aren't bad either. The music is nice, the story has both funny, serious and dark elements, and all in all - the game is fun to play. 

In my own personal list of favorite life / school simulation games, Magical Diary gets the respectful third place (where Long Live The Queen is the runner up, and Recettear: An Item Shop's Tale is the winner).

Ein sehr schönes Anime-Spiel, wobei es eigentlich weniger ein Spiel sondern eine Geschichtserzählung ist, bei deren Entwicklung man an vielen Stellen mitwirkt. 
Es hat eindeutig einen sehr hohen Wiederspielwert, weil es immer noch andere mögliche Geschichtsstränge gibt. Dabei wird man schon deshalb auf den nächsten Durchlauf neugierig, weil man von vielem ansatzweise erfährt auch wenn man den betroffenen Handlungsstrang nicht konkret spielt. 
Nach dem zweiten Durchlauf habe ich eine Komplettlösung dazu genommen um nicht versehentlich falsche Entscheidungen zu treffen. Gelegentlich wirken sich vermeintlich unwichtige Dialoge nämlich durchaus auf spätere Auswahlmöglichkeiten und Freundschaften positiv oder negativ aus. Man weiß zwar nach dem ersten Spiel, wie die Dungeons aufgebaut sind, bzw. was man zur Lösung benötigt, aber auch hier ist es interessant alternative Lösungsmöglichkeiten mit anderen Magiesorten zu finden. Zumal es nicht tragisch ist, mit den gelernten Zaubern den einen oder anderen Dungeon nicht lösen zu können. 

Zusammenfassend kann man sagen, es sind sehr schöne Geschichten, mit liebevollen, auch sehr humorigen und manchmal traurigen Dialogen, hinterlegt mit dazu passender Musik (die ich mir für passenden Preis auch holen würde, wenns sie denn gäbe). Bislang hat mir jede einzelne gespielte Geschichte (Damien, Mr. Grabiner, Donald) sehr gefallen und wer gerne liest ist hier gut aufgehoben. 

Thumbs up!

7605620.review:
A dating sim for the young witch in all of us! Like Harry Potter, with a liberal dose of anime and without all that uptight britishness that makes me kinda hate it. Also a liberal dose of progressive gender and sexuality, which is always a fun one, and racial politics too. (That said, I was a *little* offput by the 'marriage is kind of a year-long thing' plot point, even if it makes sense in context...)

Don't be fooled - this is mostly a dating/life sim. There are 'dungeons', but they're more obtuse and annoying puzzle roadblocks I could honestly do without. Persona 3/4 this ain't. Also, you have to be a girl, though you have a wide range of options for your love life, three straight and two gay, and a wide variety of other non-romance events. Romance is legitimate and well-handled - the opposite of Bioware's efforts. (Oh god, flashbacks to terrible competing english VN Planet Stronghold DDDDDDD:)

Overall, takes itself just seriously enough not to be a broad parody, but not so much that it's hard to get into or requires heavy investment. (The default character's name is Mary Sue, if that tells you anything.) Highly recommended for anyone who's even a little into the idea, and even better, sequels are on the way!

Sadly, the best character is unromanceable, despite her obviously being open to the idea of a relationship with a student and a lady. :C Oh, Professor Potsdam, how I long for some private lessons with you... ;o; (maybe she's married? i dunno.)

1594742.review:
First and foremost, let it be known this game is exactly as anime as it looks (which is pretty anime). Haters beware.

When I got this game, all I was expecting was a silly magic-themed rpg with schedule-based stat progression (you’ll see what I mean in game). After my first playthrough, it turns out there’s also a solid second half of the game in the form of adventure game-esque dungeon exams. 

Basically, you’re thrown into a small dungeon where you need to use the magic you’ve learned so far to solve a puzzle and escape. Each puzzle seems to encourage multiple approaches because of the huge number of utility spells you’ll have access to. Check the screenshot on the store page that has the spell list – the vast majority of them are more along the lines of “detect charm” and “transform stone” rather than fireball or lightning bolt, which usually means you can magical Mcgyver your way through each exam in multiple ways. This ends up being pretty important since how you develop your spell list is entirely up to you, and getting deep into one spell tree requires skimping on the others, so missing a key spell from a spell tree you’ve been neglecting isn’t a completely screwed situation if you can get creative with the other spells.

I’d like to give an example of one of my recent exams for how open-ended it can be, but I’ll post it in the comments instead in case you don’t want any of the dungeon puzzles spoiled.

As for the actual writing and story bits (which honestly make up the majority of the game, I’m definitely always itching for more of the dungeons), while the dialogue isn’t Portal levels of consistently good comedy, the characters are at least fleshed out enough to be memorable and I can safely say at least one event in game made me feel like a piece of shit for making a poor decision, so I found myself pretty invested in the setting. Turns out giving a schoolfull of teenagers magic might not always be a good idea? Oh, and the default protagonist name is Mary Sue, so the game is fairly self aware about the setting being “Harry Potter, but now I get to go!”

3508669.review: A fun, well-written visual novel with RPG elements whose cutesy anime artwork and setup as an affectionate parody of self-insert Harry Potter fanfiction disguise its depth. There are 6 possible love interests, and each one has multiple possible endings instead of just the usual good/bad. It's not a very long game, but the sheer amount of ways scenes can play out and events you can trigger encourages multiple playthroughs. The writing is great and likes to play with your expectations of both visual novels and teen fantasy romance, and the main characters and many of the minor characters are all really fleshed out. The weakest part of the game is the RPG elements -gaining skill points in certain schools of magic and using the spells you've learned to solve puzzles, which are pretty open-ended and have multiple different solutions- but the puzzles are interesting enough and offer an occasional change of pace. All-in-all, this is a game that I feel was created by someone loves visual novels and wants to see the genre become more than what it is, and really wants to see more girl-oriented games out there that aren't pieces of crap. If you like visual novels, lighthearted fantasy stories, romance games, or if you're still waiting for that Hogwarts letter, I recommend you look into this game.
